story:
World Travel Forums is a joint mission of travelers and travel companies from all over the world to create the world's largest independent online travel community.

TRAVELERS - INSPIRATION
INTERACTION - INFORMATION

Do you also love to travel the world? We started a new online adventure: join us on a journey to create world's largest independent online travel community!

In the past we created the largest online travel community for The Netherlands. Now we have a new mission: to create world's largest independent online travel community WITH TRAVELERS FROM ALL OVER THE WORLD! The launch of the community will be on July 1. The platform consists of a website, an app for iOS and Android and several social media channels.

www.worldtravelforums.net


WHO WE ARE

We are a large group of passionate travelers who really love to discover new places and new cultures. Our team is growing day by day and also you can be part of the team. World Travel Forums is made and managed by travelers and everyone can join. Meet a part of the team by clicking the 'About' link on the top right side of this page (on the left of the link 'Ask a question')


OUR GOAL

Our goal is simple: in two years World Travel Forums has to be the largest online travel community in the world. Of course we will do this step by step. We are all travelers, so we just have to realize what we want to see on an online travel community ourselves. Growth is made by expanding the team (you can be part of it!), organizing great online events about traveling and create the best experience for travelers to meet online and share information.


Help us to create world's largest online travel community!


CROWDFUNDING CAMPAIGN

We want to launch the online community big. All money raised in this crowdfunding campaign goes to the promotional budget for the launch of World Travel Forums on July 1. The launch does not depend on this campaign: the community will go live on July 1 anyway. We have a large campaign planned on Google and Facebook. Join us on this journey to create world's largest online travel community!

You can contribute the amount you want by clicking the button "BACK IT" or you can use one of the perks. Don't forget to check the Founder perk...it unlocks your secret perk!!!

THANK YOU FOR HELPING TO CREATE THE WORLD'S LARGEST ONLINE TRAVEL COMMUNITY



WORLD'S BEST TRAVEL BLOGGER 2016

Who is world's best travel blogger in 2016? Register your travel blog NOW!!!

There are three categories you can register for:

  • Instagram Travel Blogger 2016
  • YouTube Travel Vlogger 2016
  • Website Travel Blogger 2016
Get the right perk to register your travel blog.

Registration is possible during this campaign at Indiegogo untill June 30 2016. The election starts on July 1 on World Travel Forums. The Top 10 best travel bloggers for each category will be published in a WORLDWIDE PRESS RELEASE. Besides that the top 10 is published on the World Travel Forums website, our app for iOS and Android and on all social media channels. You get your own profile page about your travel blog which can be found by travelers worldwide. On your profile page you can also add photos and video about your blog and your travels. You also get a 1-year Premium World Traveler subscription for FREE.

story:
The Flammekueche is a kind of pizza that is spread with fromage blanc, then topped with slices of onions and smoky salty lardons of bacon;
an amazing dish from my beautiful region of Alsace in France.

Since my childhood this is the definitely one of my favorites recipes.
It's always a very tasty experience, easy to eat with fingers, and it pairs very well with a glass of white wine...

The Flammekueche is made following the tradition :
- Covered with a fromage blanc and crème fraîche, 
   only using products that are made in France,
- Seasoned and garnished with bacon and onions.
- And finally, cooked on stone in a French Wood-fired oven.


That is the great and unique secret of the Flammekueche taste:  Cooking !
The wood-fired oven must be around 660 degrees, then the flammekueche is perfectly cooked in only 2 minutes by the oven bottom as well as flamed from the roof. This process is key. And this is why with my husband, we've imported a special low ceiling oven straight from France.

Flammekueche origins
Back in the day, the farmer's wife would put the Flammekueche directly
into the oven with the shovel to be baked, then cut into pieces
that people would then bend or roll with their fingers to eat them.
The Flammekueche is traditionally eaten until satiety with good beers or wines: Riesling, Sylvaner, Pinot...
I'm confident that you will love its simplicity, originality, taste and the overall Flammekueche experience.

My name is Anne Besset

With my husband and our 5 children, we've been living in Upper Rockridge, Oakland for 18 months now.
I've worked hard for months to introduce Flammekueche to my new home.

Help me to create a restaurant 
to bring the atmosphere of Alsace & deliver more Bay Area people

I started my delivery and take-out business 6 months ago, and all the Americans who have tried it have loved it!  
This is why I want to bring a piece of Alsace and my childhood to America
with a Flammekueche restaurant, bringing the atmosphere of Alsace
and introduce my recipe to more Bay Area residents! 

The recipes


                     ______________________________________________

- Discount for future purchases of our Flammekueches
  (Home delivery & catering)!
- Parties & Dinners at my restaurant!


- But also a huge thank you on my website, my Facebook page,
  and in my future restaurant!

+ A certificate, as a sponsor of La Flamme

story_txt:
The Flammekueche is a kind of pizza that is spread with fromage blanc, then topped with slices of onions and smoky salty lardons of bacon; an amazing dish from my beautiful region of Alsace in France.Since my childhood this is the definitely one of my favorites recipes.It's always a very tasty experience, easy to eat with fingers, and it pairs very well with a glass of white wine...
The Flammekueche is made following the tradition :- Covered with a fromage blanc and crème fraîche,    only using products that are made in France, - Seasoned and garnished with bacon and onions.- And finally, cooked on stone in a French Wood-fired oven.That is the great and unique secret of the Flammekueche taste:  Cooking !The wood-fired oven must be around 660 degrees, then the flammekueche is perfectly cooked in only 2 minutes by the oven bottom as well as flamed from the roof. This process is key. And this is why with my husband, we've imported a special low ceiling oven straight from France.Flammekueche originsBack in the day, the farmer's wife would put the Flammekueche directly into the oven with the shovel to be baked, then cut into pieces that people would then bend or roll with their fingers to eat them.The Flammekueche is traditionally eaten until satiety with good beers or wines: Riesling, Sylvaner, Pinot...I'm confident that you will love its simplicity, originality, taste and the overall Flammekueche experience.


My name is Anne Besset



With my husband and our 5 children, we've been living in Upper Rockridge, Oakland for 18 months now. 
I've worked hard for months to introduce Flammekueche to my new home.



Help me to create a restaurant to bring the atmosphere of Alsace & deliver more Bay Area people


I started my delivery and take-out business 6 months ago, and all the Americans who have tried it have loved it!  
This is why I want to bring a piece of Alsace and my childhood to America with a Flammekueche restaurant, bringing the atmosphere of Alsace 
and introduce my recipe to more Bay Area residents! The recipes

story:
Hello loyal and potential customers of Wilson’s BBQ. I am Leroy Wilson, Owner of Wilson’s BBQ restaurant where for over four (10) years we have provided our customers award winning BBQ and excellent service.We provide exceptional customer service and serve award winning cuisines. Wilson’s BBQ has been blessed to realize consistent growth and extraordinary customer satisfaction over the past ten years since its establishment. Today, we express sincere thanks for your loyal support of our Fort Worth store located on the North East edge of the Meadowbrook Neighborhood. Wilson’s BBQ has been exceedingly blessed as we have enjoyed consistent growth and customer satisfaction over the past four (4) years in Meadowbrook; we sincerely thank you for your loyal support.

I come to you today seeking your help in the expansion of my lifelong passion and vision of providing the best BBQ, “OURS” in the DFW Metroplex to those who don’t have access to us. Wilson’s BBQ will launch “Have Smoke Will Travel” with the purchase of a mobile food truck where we will bring our products and staff to your home, special event, place of business, Church or any location you prefer.  We are asking you, the community to support our efforts by making a donation via the Indiegogo funding platform. You can see that Wilson’s BBQ is also committed to the community, we are providing incentives to those who share our vision, and make a donation.

 You may ask “what will be the outcome” of your help?  By reaching our financial goal we will deploy a mobile food truck, expand our business , ,reaching more people seeking the best BBQ in the Metroplex. This business expansion allows us to create more jobs and to continue our philosophy of employing ex-offenders who have proven their desire to learn the BBQ Trade and become productive tax paying citizens.

What We Need & What You Get
We need $25, 000.00 to purchase a BBQ Mobile Food Truck ,so that we can expand our business around the Dallas/Fort Worth  Metroplex. Wilson's is prepared to give incentives to our contributors for certain levels of financial support; please look at the incentives.  

  • Susan T.
  • Granbury, TX

    • 2/1/2016

    Just had a catered lunch for 25 people at my workplace.  Leroy, the owner, delivered the food  on time in 25 dinner containers.  Everyone appreciated the individual dinners instead of having it buffet style.  I ordered brisket, sausage, chicken, potato salad and coleslaw.  Everything was delicious and got rave reviews from the rest of the staff.  All of the meat was tender and had just the right amount of smoke flavor.  I highly recommend Wilson's if you want great BB

  • Austin C.
  • Arlington, TX

    • 12/27/2015

    Wilson's is the best BBQ I've ever had, and I've waited for 4 hours to eat at Franklin's in Austin. The people are always friendly to newcomers.

  • Joseph W.
  • Kamas, UT

    • 12/7/2015

    Best BBQ I've ever had. I've tried all around Texas and never had better ribs nor sausage. Leroy, the owner, is also the nicest man around! Completely enjoyed the food, including the delicious sides of potato salad and beans. I've made a one hour drive out of my way just to go!

  • Chris W.
  • Arlington, TX

    • 3/15/2014

    Can't believe I've lived in West Arlington for over 4 years and I'm just finding out about Wilson's BBQ. I ordered the ribs and when given the choice of having the sauce on top or in the side, I opted to have it put on top. Great choice. The rib meat was so tender that it was falling right off the bone. And the sauce was very tasty. It was more of an au jus than a traditional BBQ sauce, but it added to the moistness of the overall meal. 

    It's going to be dangerous now that I know this place is only a few miles from home.

    The Impact

    Over the past four (4) years we have have customers travel as far as from Denton, Texas, and far East Dallas (Garland) just to find the most delicious BBQ in the geographic region of DFW. We also have been invited to many out door meetings and festivals offering our menu of ribs, beef, pull pork, chicken, links and our stuffed baked potato. With the provision of our Mobile Food Truck, we can travel to those who seek us but cannot get to us.

    Wilson's BBQ and it's owner Leroy Wilson, are believers of the rule of "Second Chance". Wilson's has been successful in offering gainful, part time and full time employment to EX-Offenders who return and seek redemption. This business expansion will create new jobs and the opportunity for Wilson's to continue to help those who are ex-offenders seeking a changed life experience. 

    Risks & Challenges

    Our new expansion is not a departure from our core business principals that started over ten (10) years ago when we opened our first store ,in West Fort Worth in the Lake Como Community. We believe that if we provide the best food and the best service people will return for more and spread the word. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Please post this fund raising campaign on your Facebook and all social media platforms. Spread by word of mouth what we are trying to do, and come by our store in Meadowbrook for the best BBQ in North Texas.

story:
Kurzbeschreibung

Die PonyTruppe Dresden bietet mit ihrem Konzept bereits ganz jungen Pferdefans die Möglichkeit, den Kontakt zu ihrem Lieblingstier herzustellen, alles über es zu lernen und das Körpergefühl, die Balance und Fitness von Kindern durch individuellen Reitunterricht schon in der frühkindlichen Entwicklung zu unterstützen.
Hierbei geben wir nicht einfach nur Reitstunden. Jeder Reitschüler übernimmt auch die Vorbereitung seines Pferdes auf den Reitunterricht.
Weiterhin unterstützen wir mit Lehrgängen Konzentrations- und Begeisterungsfähigkeit auf die Altersgruppen abgestimmt, und fördern Charaktereigenschaften wie Verantwortungsbewusstsein, Toleranz, Selbstbewusstsein und Fairness. Die Arbeit mit Pferden eignet sich hier hervorragend.
Dank einem großen Zuspruch wollen wir den Schritt auf ein eigenes Gelände wagen und dort ein Paradies für Kinder entstehen lassen. Gegenwärtig nutzen wir noch die Vorteile einer hervorragenden Anlage, sind jedoch zu stark gewachsen um dort bleiben zu können.
Mit den durch die Kampagne erzielten Mitteln, werden die Investitionen für das Reitparadies vervollständigt. Wir möchten unsere speziell auf die Förderung von Reitanfängern, egal welchen Alters, abgeschnittenen Pläne umsetzen. 
In unseren Videos und generell auf dem Videokanal der PonyTruppe, können Sie zusätzlich in unsere Arbeit reinschnuppern.

Was wir für Sie umsetzen
Die wesentlichen Bestandteile der Finanzierung liegen im Bau eines Offenstalls für artgerechte Pferdehaltung, in der Sicherung der Tier und Einzäunung des Areals und im Anlegen des Reitplatzes:
 
     
  • Der Stall, bzw das Hauptgebäude befindet sich auf einem schwebenden Fundament und ist von einem Dachdeckermeister konzipiert.  Auf diese Weise können wir nicht nur sicher stellen, dass es sich um einen durchdachten Bau handelt, wir haben zusätzlich immer die Chance das Gebäude zu transportieren, zu verändern und bei Modernisierung zu verkaufen. Dies stärkt unsere unternehmerische Flexibilität und stellt langfristig die artgerechte Unterkunft unserer Pferde sicher.
    •  
  • Bei der Sicherung der Pferde und Umzäunung des Areals setzen wir auf Qualität und wissen welcher Verantwortung wir dabei gegenüber stehen. Schließlich hat der Schutz der Lieblinge unserer Reitschüler oberste Priorität.
    •  
  • Der dritte wesentliche Punkt, in welchen die Mittel der Kampagne fließen sollen, ist ein spezieller Reitplatz. Ein spezieller Fließuntergrund stellt sicher, dass wir in jeder Jahreszeit und bei jedem Wetter arbeiten und den Ansprüchen von Pferd und Reiter gerecht werden können. Weiterhin werden Stürze von Reitanfängern ideal aufgefangen und das Verletzungsrisiko wird minimiert.
    •  
Auf diesen drei Bausteinen baut die Umsetzung des Plans im neuen Areal auf.
Für diese Investitionen benötigen wir Ihre Hilfe.

Die Folgen
Mit der Umsetzung der Pläne schaffen wir gemeinsam ein Areal, auf dem unsere Kinder und mit Ihnen natürlich auch deren Familien sich sinnvoll in ihrer Freizeit beschäftigen können. 

Auf dem eigenen Gelände können wir optimale Haltungsbedingungen für unsere Pferde, Flexibilität in der Terminvergabe und einen Standort für mehr tolle Veranstaltungen bieten, als dies unsere Kunden jetzt schon von uns gewöhnt sind.

Wir konnten unser Projekt bereits beim Veterinäramt vorstellen und erhielten Zuspruch. 

Handwerkliche Unterstützung beim Bau und Nutzung verschiedener Expertise wurde uns ebenfalls bereits zugesichert.

Es gilt die Chance der Verbesserung eines tollen Unternehmerkonzeptes für Kinder zu realisieren, wobei wir Ihr Vertrauen nicht enttäuschen werden.

 


Risiken & Herausforderungen

Die PonyTruppe Dresden ist sich der Herausforderungen des Projektes bewusst und scheut keine Mühen diese zu bewältigen.
Neben der artgerechten Versorgung unserer Tiere, steht die Zufriedenstellung unserer Kunden im Vordergrund.
Die größte Herausforderung liegt dabei in der Personalplanung. Der neue Standort ist gut zu erreichen und ermöglicht  uns bessere Chancen auf Fachkräfte.
Dem Einfluss von Schlechtwetterzeiten werden wir vor allem mittels des besonderen Reitplatzbodens, aber auch durch einen beheizten Aufenthaltsraum entgegenwirken.
  

Andere Wege, wie man helfen kann

Wir hoffen durch diesen kurzen Einblick, Ihren Zuspruch gewonnen zu haben und sind dankbar, sollten Sie sich für die finanzielle Unterstützung unseres Projektes entscheiden.

Ebenso möchten wir uns bei Ihnen für die Hilfe auf anderen Wegen bedanken:

     
  • Wenn Ihnen unsere Ideen gefallen, berichten Sie doch Freunden und Familien davon. Alle finden unser Konzept auf der Plattform von Indiegogo und können sich selbst ein Bild machen.
    •  
  • Kontaktdaten der PonyTruppe Dresden finden Sie überall online, sollten Sie eine andere Unterstützeridee verfolgen
    •  
Es grüßt Sie herzlich, das Team der PonyTruppe Dresden

story:
My Story...

Nearly two years ago, I dropped out of university, becoming one of millions of university students around the world who, for various reasons, drop out before graduation year. In my case, it was familial financial constraints. To sustain me in school hundreds of miles away, my family sometimes went without food. Sometimes, from the little that I earned from a writing stint, I sent home. Dropping out became inevitable. One morning, I applied for an indefinite break and headed home with one objective: find a job. Anything. My graduation year would have been 2017. 

Having worked for three years after high school to save up for university, dropping out barely half way into my three and a half year journalism course at USIU, Nairobi, Kenya, quickly set me on a path of emotional breakdown. It had all ended faster than it had started; one moment I was a hopeful freshman keen on finishing school in record time... the next, I was stuffing my few belongings in a bag and heading home.

Once home, I was back at a familiar place of uncertainty. It was that uncertainty that had led me to find work after high school in a bid to save up for university education. Within three years, I learned and worked my way into becoming a prime-time radio newscaster at Radiocity 97FM, despite being without any kind of university or college training. A year and a half after I enrolled for university, what made dropping out particularly hard was not that I needed school to discover myself or my potential but the fact that with the break, my ultimate journalistic dreams were taking a back seat, again. Nevertheless, blinded by the urge to help my family, I started the knocking. Door after door. 

It wasn't long before I was reminded of the sole reason why I have always wanted to get done with school. Despite my experience, proven ability to learn fast and passion, that I didn't have a degree was something many employers fronted as the only reason why they couldn't take me on. 

Meanwhile, things were either the same at home or deteriorating; my young brother soon dropped out of high school in order for my sister to continue with her IT degree. She is currently in her second year. Something positive. 

With my job search yielding nothing, alongside whatever my parents could raise, I used my small savings to start up a 300-bird chicken project. Given my limited capital base, it soon ran into setbacks that thinned the already marginal profits. 

Frustrated, I slowly drowned deeper in my own mental pool of worry. What started as occasional lack of sleep and mild headaches soon grew into something more serious: depression. It wasn't just about my dreams but even those of my two siblings. I worried that they were doomed to the same fate. I was angry about how things had turned out for my parents; they'd toiled selflessly for others but had little to show for their laudable efforts. 

After months of almosts, my current $600 p.m job came. Since November 2015, I have worked as the online content editor at NBS Television, a leading player in Uganda's broadcasting industry. Getting the job brought much-needed relief; it came with a chance of being back in a newsroom, human contact... it gave me a shield against my worries, aided my healing process and above all else, a shot at survival. 

But I don't want to survive. I watched my father survive and sacrifice for his family my entire life. I want more than to survive. 

Fishing My Dreams...

Ultimately, I want to start up a production company to tell the many untold stories of Uganda and Africa at large. In between, I want to position myself better by finishing school; I want not to be told that I am the perfect person for the job save for the fact that I lack a mere paper. Being in a position to help out my family, though limited, brings joy but I don't want that to be the reason why my own dreams sink down into oblivion with each passing day.

That is why I am asking for help. I seek a total of US$3,325 (the exact equivalent of UGX11.1M) to start up a fish farm, an 8-month project capable of fivefold profitability. 

As per this breakdown drawn up by Geossy Ltd, US$1,797 (UGX6M) would be spent on constructing a 125 m3 cage with a holding capacity of 10,000 heads of Tilapia. Fish feeding equipment and a boat are also covered. 

The US$1,527 (UGX5.1M) buys the Tilapia fingerlings, the feeds and labour for the 8-month  growth process. 


As shown below, US$3,325 (UGX11.1M), over a period of eight months yields a production cycle revenue of US$15,099 (UGX50.4M) and net profits totalling to US$11,773 (UGX39.3M). These figures factor in a mortality rate of 10% (1,000 of the 10,000 heads) and a per kilogramme US$2 (UGX8,000) price for the projected 6,300kgs harvestable after the eight months. 


It would take me five months of saving every penny I currently earn to raise the money I need for this project. If only I could. It would take me two whole years, as per my current salary scheme to save up the equivalent of the profits that this project forecasts within eight months. 

With the money, the plan is to use the initial cage to fund a minimum of 5 cages within three years. The cage will be constructed at home where there is enough space for at least one such cage. Eventually, I intend to buy some land to accommodate expansion or apply for a license to farm on Lake Victoria. 

What your contribution will help me achieve...

Apart from achieving the main goal of starting the project and funding it until the time when mature fish will be pulled out of the cage, the outcome of the project is one of hope. Hope that I will be able to afford finishing school, pay for my siblings' education and support my parents who're both not earning any money. Hope that with fewer needs to worry about, my own recovery process would be aided. Hope that within a few years, I will be able to afford the resources needed to start up and run a production house. Hope that even amid efforts to help my family, my own dreams will not be lost in the process. 

Thank you. 

MWESIGWA SAMUEL-STONE SONGA 


*Attached supporting video: Michael Baleke/CCTV
story_txt:
My Story...

Nearly two years ago, I dropped out of university, becoming one of millions of university students around the world who, for various reasons, drop out before graduation year. In my case, it was familial financial constraints. To sustain me in school hundreds of miles away, my family sometimes went without food. Sometimes, from the little that I earned from a writing stint, I sent home. Dropping out became inevitable. One morning, I applied for an indefinite break and headed home with one objective: find a job. Anything. My graduation year would have been 2017. 
Having worked for three years after high school to save up for university, dropping out barely half way into my three and a half year journalism course at USIU, Nairobi, Kenya, quickly set me on a path of emotional breakdown. It had all ended faster than it had started; one moment I was a hopeful freshman keen on finishing school in record time... the next, I was stuffing my few belongings in a bag and heading home.
Once home, I was back at a familiar place of uncertainty. It was that uncertainty that had led me to find work after high school in a bid to save up for university education. Within three years, I learned and worked my way into becoming a prime-time radio newscaster at Radiocity 97FM, despite being without any kind of university or college training. A year and a half after I enrolled for university, what made dropping out particularly hard was not that I needed school to discover myself or my potential but the fact that with the break, my ultimate journalistic dreams were taking a back seat, again. Nevertheless, blinded by the urge to help my family, I started the knocking. Door after door. 

It wasn't long before I was reminded of the sole reason why I have always wanted to get done with school. Despite my experience, proven ability to learn fast and passion, that I didn't have a degree was something many employers fronted as the only reason why they couldn't take me on. 
Meanwhile, things were either the same at home or deteriorating; my young brother soon dropped out of high school in order for my sister to continue with her IT degree. She is currently in her second year. Something positive. 
With my job search yielding nothing, alongside whatever my parents could raise, I used my small savings to start up a 300-bird chicken project. Given my limited capital base, it soon ran into setbacks that thinned the already marginal profits. 
Frustrated, I slowly drowned deeper in my own mental pool of worry. What started as occasional lack of sleep and mild headaches soon grew into something more serious: depression. It wasn't just about my dreams but even those of my two siblings. I worried that they were doomed to the same fate. I was angry about how things had turned out for my parents; they'd toiled selflessly for others but had little to show for their laudable efforts. 
After months of almosts, my current $600 p.m job came. Since November 2015, I have worked as the online content editor at NBS Television, a leading player in Uganda's broadcasting industry. Getting the job brought much-needed relief; it came with a chance of being back in a newsroom, human contact... it gave me a shield against my worries, aided my healing process and above all else, a shot at survival. 
But I don't want to survive. I watched my father survive and sacrifice for his family my entire life. I want more than to survive. 
Fishing My Dreams...
Ultimately, I want to start up a production company to tell the many untold stories of Uganda and Africa at large. In between, I want to position myself better by finishing school; I want not to be told that I am the perfect person for the job save for the fact that I lack a mere paper. Being in a position to help out my family, though limited, brings joy but I don't want that to be the reason why my own dreams sink down into oblivion with each passing day.
That is why I am asking for help. I seek a total of US$3,325 (the exact equivalent of UGX11.1M) to start up a fish farm, an 8-month project capable of fivefold profitability. 
As per this breakdown drawn up by Geossy Ltd, US$1,797 (UGX6M) would be spent on constructing a 125 m3 cage with a holding capacity of 10,000 heads of Tilapia. Fish feeding equipment and a boat are also covered. 
The US$1,527 (UGX5.1M) buys the Tilapia fingerlings, the feeds and labour for the 8-month  growth process. 



As shown below, US$3,325 (UGX11.1M), over a period of eight months yields a production cycle revenue of US$15,099 (UGX50.4M) and net profits totalling to US$11,773 (UGX39.3M). These figures factor in a mortality rate of 10% (1,000 of the 10,000 heads) and a per kilogramme US$2 (UGX8,000) price for the projected 6,300kgs harvestable after the eight months. 

It would take me five months of saving every penny I currently earn to raise the money I need for this project. If only I could. It would take me two whole years, as per my current salary scheme to save up the equivalent of the profits that this project forecasts within eight months. 
With the money, the plan is to use the initial cage to fund a minimum of 5 cages within three years. The cage will be constructed at home where there is enough space for at least one such cage. Eventually, I intend to buy some land to accommodate expansion or apply for a license to farm on Lake Victoria. 
What your contribution will help me achieve...
Apart from achieving the main goal of starting the project and funding it until the time when mature fish will be pulled out of the cage, the outcome of the project is one of hope. Hope that I will be able to afford finishing school, pay for my siblings' education and support my parents who're both not earning any money. Hope that with fewer needs to worry about, my own recovery process would be aided. Hope that within a few years, I will be able to afford the resources needed to start up and run a production house. Hope that even amid efforts to help my family, my own dreams will not be lost in the process. 
Thank you. 
MWESIGWA SAMUEL-STONE SONGA 

*Attached supporting video: Michael Baleke/CCTV

story:
A Who and A Where?

I, Jonathan, started 310HIGHROAD in Los Angeles, CA as a way to increase the overall employee health and lifestyle while providing consumers with the most direct and personal furniture shopping experience he could think of. Subconsciously for the past 5+ years, I have been brainstorming in a way that will change the work force and ecommerce experience for the better. My background in customer service and operational functions at previous places of employment have helped develop 310HIGHROAD into what it is today.

The 310HIGHROAD campaign was started out of a necessity to improve overall mental and physical health in creating new things, while doing what I do best - giving back and helping others. I am developing a way for employees to be more productive with less of the stress factors of life, while improving the customer service and ecommerce buying experience for furniture and home goods or accessories. The campaign is so near and dear to my heart, I named the company after the address of the home I grew up in. There's something about that brick home back in the suburbs of Chicago that was always so inviting, relaxing, loving, and comforting that I am able to close my eyes and pretend I am sitting in the living room with the summer breeze blowing through the house, the birds outside are chirping at the squirrels on the bird feeder, the dogs are barking at who knows what, cows across the street are mooing, and mom is in the kitchen preparing the pot roast for dinner. 

I'm sure some of you reading this are instantly taken back to that home with me. Can you smell the flowers and feel the breeze as it blows through the house? Do you hear the birds? Do you look outside the window and smile from the sunshine hitting your face? That's what home is and I want to share that with everyone. How we're raised, where we're raised, and how comfortable you feel inside your home are extremely important to your overall health. I will replicate that exact idea through 310HIGHROAD on both ends - one for the consumer in their shopping experience and purchases and the other for the employee in their workplace atmosphere. As a contributor, you will help make this dream a reality.


Simply put...Think of us as a personal design ecommerce presence that will handle all of your decorating needs. We will be there through every step of the way offering design consultations and advice from on staff professionals. Our team of experts will also manage the ecommerce store based on your particular interests - colors, concepts, particular furniture eras, re-purposing ideas for items you've found on our site, vintage furniture sourcing, and so much more! The possibilities of what 310HIGHROAD will be able to offer you are limitless.



Your Home. Your Lifestyle. Here's the "deets"

Listen, I'll be honest. I can't do this alone and quite frankly, I don't want to. I like be surrounded by people who are looking out for the good and success in others.

Currently, my goal of $125,000 will be directly related to building the brand and all it encompasses.
~$10,000 will go directly to strategically building out the website and phone apps for a streamlined eCommerce buying experience. I want to be as detailed as possible for consumers - think of it as a personal shopping experience for your home. Need design help? Call, text, email, smoke signal us - I want to be there to help!
~$35,000 is going to secure one hell of a building and office environment. Each office inside the building will be dedicated to a room in a home (whoever gets the bathroom as their office, I will make sure it is only a showroom and NOT in working order). Working with our furniture and home goods suppliers, I would love the skilled and hand-picked team to receive a quarterly budget to make their office as inviting as possible. Imagine now you're in your living room at home, but thinking of the company atmosphere - what would you like to see? Grab a vendor catalog and place an order - make 310HIGHROAD like your home.
~$10,000 will be used to concept a 310HIGHROAD collection of furniture and home goods line, but will also be used to secure immediate furniture sales for the eCommerce buying experience. 
~$10,000 has to go towards supplies, marketing, and normal office admin expenses.
~$60,000 will make the future a success as we build the brand and secure employment. Think of it as a secure piggy bank for the company to be financially responsible and consistent.

In case we don't reach our exact goal, the funds will be evenly distributed on a percentage basis across the board. The funding topics above are the heart and soul of the company and deserve attention.

Perk Me Up!

Who doesn't love a perk? I know I do. Look what's in store for you:

  • A personalized Thank You postcard from Jonathan
  • Helping Mother Earth breathe life with freshly planted flowers or trees at the new office
  • Stainless steel reusable water bottles
  • Sturdy reusable tote bags
  • Large proud backer stamps the company will use on outgoing packages in your name
  • Hand-picked box of your interests in furniture and/or home goods
  • A room inside our "home" office named after you
  • Free ground shipping up to 6 months
  • A piece of furniture or home good named after you and the first one off the production line!
  • To be a part of history and 310HIGHROAD forever


Hurdles We Face:

To keep with being honest - there's a lot at stake. I am deeply appreciative of everyone who contributes and everyone who believes in me, but it will be my sole responsibility to keep the company running and employees happy. Spending time running through the "what if" questions in my head is enough to drive me crazy, but then I stop and think the "what if" turns into What if we are so successful as a brand and lifestyle, all employees receive more time off or are guaranteed a bonus? That's what make me happy.

Writing everything down, planning for the future, accounting for growth, looking at all possible obstacles - this will help make a strong foundation for what the company stands for and plans to execute.


Contribution for 310HIGHROAD is not solely monetary.

Although a monetary contribution helps - spreading the word about 310HIGHROAD is the greatest compliment I could think of. From the bottom of my heart - I will not give up on you and thank you in advance for even taking the time to read the campaign.

Remember to like and follow the campaign, share it with your friends on Facebook, Tweet about us, Instagram connect with us @310HIGHROAD, attach the link on your blog, and tell your family about the good deeds we are trying to put into action.

story:
mNaukri connects slum residents to local employment opportunities that are individually catered to their needs, more often than not jobs that are task-oriented, short-term, easy to complete. 

Our Inspiration.

Slums are vibrant economic ecosystems. Name any industry or service, slums have it – bangles, sanitary pads, catering, leather purses, babysitting. Despite these systems, unemployment is rampant. Why this disconnect?

Lack of access to information. 

Slum residents currently receive information about jobs from middlemen who charge exorbitant fees without even guaranteeing employment. When middlemen connect residents to jobs, they tend to be far away from the slum, practically inaccessible to reach. As a result, many slum residents have stopped looking for jobs altogether. For single mothers like Santoshi, it's simply too time-consuming, expensive, and inefficient. 

So we asked ourselves. What could we do to help Santoshi and millions like her? How could we start an international movement to end unemployment in urban slums? That's when mNaukri was born. 

Our Solution. 

Locally built and globally financed, mNaukri combines the sucesses of the past and the present to build trust, connect communities, and empower through employment. We connect slum residents to local employment opportunities that are individually catered to their needs, more often than not jobs that are task-oriented, short-term, easy to complete. How exactly do we do this? 

Three simple steps. You help us build. We connect. Together we employ.
 
1) YOU BUILD. With your initial investment, we build kiosks within urban slums in partnership with local convenience (kirana) stores. These kiosks are equipped with trained counselors from the community who facilitate face-to-face interaction for residents looking for jobs. Each kiosk costs only about $2,500 to create and can provide more than five thousands jobs annually.  


2) WE CONNECT. Slum residents then create a profile on our mobile platform with help from the counselor. Our algorithm connects slum residents to task-oriented, short-term jobs within their slum. No need to travel far. Hours flexible. 



3) TOGETHER WE EMPLOY. That's it! It's that simple. The whole process repeats after the slum resident has rated the quality of their employer. No more middlemen! Plus, residents only pay us a small fee after they've completed the job! 



Our Business Model. 

We employ a unique micro-franchise model to empower our customers to become entrepreneurs. Our franchisees generate revenue through two means. 
  • Commissions. Franchisees collect fixed commissions from job seekers that are less than tenth the cost of what middlemen currently charge. These commissions are only collected if a counselor can successfully match a slum resident to a local employer. Otherwise the service is FREE-OF-CHARGE. 
  • Print Advertisements. Franchisees can also utilize their hot real estate space within the center of urban slums as a space for print advertisements from local household goods shop owners. 
We also provide all kiosk owners/franchisees with performance-based seed funding to catalyze the set-up of kiosk operations, training to use our unique job-sourcing mobile platform, and branding. And if that's not enough, we also provide our franchisees with a guaranteed salary of Rs. 7500/month as long as they show an effort to attract customers and maintain high customer satisfaction ratings. As one of our anticipated franchisees mentioned, "it truly is a win-win situation to be a part of the [mNaukri] brand."

Our Impact

In our first year of operations, we aim to create 10 kiosks in 10 slum communities within Mumbai, India, matching residents to temporary, task economy oriented jobs.  Within five years, we will establish 500 kiosks across major cities in India generating approximately $813.6m in direct cumulative social return from the number of idle hours converted into productive hours. mNaukri will also increase trust between employers and employees and boost under-capitalized slum economies.

Our Team 

Our team has more than fifteen years combined experience working in slums directly with young women and children. As a result, we strongly rely on the diverse voices of people living in these communities and the networks we have built on-the-ground to guide our quest to double income in crowded urban spaces. Equipped with the tools of economics, neuroscience, public policy, and social innovation, we are an interdisciplinary team of impatient optimists excited to tackle unmet social needs and translate our idea into direct impact.

In The Media 


Our T-Shirt Design (Duke ONLY Special!)

story:
Our Story

  A chef (Matt) and a brewer (Callah) started The Tiny Acre farm in the winter of 2015 on a small plot of leased land in the quiet corner of Woodstock, Ct. We are first generation young farmers practicing bio-intensive farming techniques committed to growing diverse, delicious and nutritious produce for our community. Our first growing season, we started a small CSA (community supported agriculture) program of 15 members. Some of the items we grew:

salad greens, radishes, turnips, celery, carrots, mini onions, various greens, beets, green beans, snap peas, eggplant, peppers, tomatoes, squash, melons, cucumber, culinary herbs and a variety of cut flowers. 



  After the success of our first year, we were obviously very excited to start planning an even more successful second year. This includes some major ground breaking (literally) plans as we expand our 1/4 acre growing space to a full acre. The main component to making this a success is, you guessed it, a GREENHOUSE!

  With your help (and a little elbow grease) we want to build a greenhouse on the farm to vastly expand the potential of our second growing season, and beyond. A large greenhouse at The Tiny Acre will allow us to:

  • Increase our CSA capacity from 15 members, to 40. That means providing 40 families with fresh, local produce all season long! 
  • Become full-time vendors at two farmers markets (Spring, Summer & Fall).
  • House 40 additional tomato plants during peak Summer season as a bumper crop.
  • Grow vegetables year round, making local produce more accessible to our community in the colder months.

What We Need

  To reach our goal, we have proposed a budget of $2500. These funds get broken down into 4 categories:

  • Greenhouse build-out (all materials for framework, metal poles, lumber, poly film, gables ends, hardware etc.)
  • Propagation materials (seed trays, flats, heating mats, seeding mix, germination chamber ect).
  • Shelving (enough greenhouse benches to fit 60 seedling trays).
  • Miscellaneous expenses (hosing, hand tools, thermometer, fans, tomato trellising etc.) 
  


  If we exceed our goal, additional funds from this campaign will go towards upgrades on the greenhouse such as a heater and more propagation space as well as renovating existing garage space here on the farm for a farm stand open weekly to the public. 


What You Get

  Besides getting some pretty awesome perks from us for contributing to our campaign, this project gives back in a variety ways. Not only are you helping a small business thrive and providing a local community more access to fresh and sustainable food, you are making it possible for small farms around the world to make a big impact on the local food movement. New farmers are necessary for our future in food as the average age of an American farmer is 57, and getting older every year. To reverse this course, we must take bold action to ensure that aspiring farmers have access to land, health care, capital, education and training. By helping The Tiny Acre, you are helping all beginning farmers become the next generation of farmers our country so desperately needs. 

  You don't have to be local to feel good about helping our campaign. We have partnered with a local food pantry, so any perks redeemed that come with produce can be donated to them if you are unable to come to the farm yourself. 


   


Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute, doesn't mean you can't be part of our success. Other great ways to help us reach our goal:

  • Make some noise about it! Scream about it! Dance about it!
  • SHARE SHARE SHARE and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for reading about our journey and we hope to see everyone this upcoming season, whether it be at the farm or at a farmer's market. We are very excited!

Our Story   A chef (Matt) and a brewer (Callah) started The Tiny Acre farm in the winter of 2015 on a small plot of leased land in the quiet corner of Woodstock, Ct. We are first generation young farmers practicing bio-intensive farming techniques committed to growing diverse, delicious and nutritious produce for our community. Our first growing season, we started a small CSA (community supported agriculture) program of 15 members. Some of the items we grew:
salad greens, radishes, turnips, celery, carrots, mini onions, various greens, beets, green beans, snap peas, eggplant, peppers, tomatoes, squash, melons, cucumber, culinary herbs and a variety of cut flowers. 




  After the success of our first year, we were obviously very excited to start planning an even more successful second year. This includes some major ground breaking (literally) plans as we expand our 1/4 acre growing space to a full acre. The main component to making this a success is, you guessed it, a GREENHOUSE!
  With your help (and a little elbow grease) we want to build a greenhouse on the farm to vastly expand the potential of our second growing season, and beyond. A large greenhouse at The Tiny Acre will allow us to:  Increase our CSA capacity from 15 members, to 40. That means providing 40 families with fresh, local produce all season long!  Become full-time vendors at two farmers markets (Spring, Summer & Fall).
House 40 additional tomato plants during peak Summer season as a bumper crop. Grow vegetables year round, making local produce more accessible to our community in the colder months.

   What We Need   To reach our goal, we have proposed a budget of $2500. These funds get broken down into 4 categories:  
Greenhouse build-out (all materials for framework, metal poles, lumber, poly film, gables ends, hardware etc.)

Propagation materials (seed trays, flats, heating mats, seeding mix, germination chamber ect).

Shelving (enough greenhouse benches to fit 60 seedling trays).

Miscellaneous expenses (hosing, hand tools, thermometer, fans, tomato trellising etc.) 

  

  If we exceed our goal, additional funds from this campaign will go towards upgrades on the greenhouse such as a heater and more propagation space as well as renovating existing garage space here on the farm for a farm stand open weekly to the public. 



What You Get   Besides getting some pretty awesome perks from us for contributing to our campaign, this project gives back in a variety ways. Not only are you helping a small business thrive and providing a local community more access to fresh and sustainable food, you are making it possible for small farms around the world to make a big impact on the local food movement. New farmers are necessary for our future in food as the average age of an American farmer is 57, and getting older every year. To reverse this course, we must take bold action to ensure that aspiring farmers have access to land, health care, capital, education and training. By helping The Tiny Acre, you are helping all beginning farmers become the next generation of farmers our country so desperately needs. 
  You don't have to be local to feel good about helping our campaign. We have partnered with a local food pantry, so any perks redeemed that come with produce can be donated to them if you are unable to come to the farm yourself. 


   


    Other Ways You Can Help Just because you can't contribute, doesn't mean you can't be part of our success. Other great ways to help us reach our goal:  Make some noise about it! Scream about it! Dance about it! SHARE SHARE SHARE and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!


Thank you so much for reading about our journey and we hope to see everyone this upcoming season, whether it be at the farm or at a farmer's market. We are very excited!

story:
In July of 2015, I had the good fortune to take over a small 34 seat café in a Davidson Business Courtyard in my hometown, Smiths Falls Ontario. I thought this was a perfect opportunity to promote local foods by creating menu items from farmers and growers, so in August, Café 7 West opened its doors again with a new menu and a fresher approach to food!

I created a 'localcentric' menu using local food distributor, Wendy's Mobile Market of Lyndhurst Ontario for access to beef, pork, chicken, eggs, greens vegetables, cheese and more from local producers. I chose a secondary supplier, J Quattrocchi, a local wholesale food distributor that has been operating since 1922 right here in Smiths Falls.  I have received tremendous support from Two Rivers Food Hub and have established clientele from the local community as well as local food enthusiasts from surrounding towns and cities including Almonte, Brockville, Kemptville, Kingston, Lanark, Merrickville, Napanee and Perth. 

My challenge creating a menu with fresh foods in a 7 ft x 7 ft kitchen that was equipped with a conventional stove without a range hood or a fire suppression system. I was roasting meats, baking breads and desserts most every day due to very little storage and worked mostly by myself. I have a fantastic server who checks in for lunch service when needed, a wonderful niece who works on the weekend and a childhood friend who assists with my baking production one night a week.

While I received both verbal and social media feedback on how much my food was enjoyed and appreciated, I was not getting the walk in traffic throughout the day necessary to making the sales and growth projected. There is also so much more I would like to offer in the way of locally produced products. My goal is to offer frozen prepared meals, soups, stocks and stews along with shelf stable products from other local producers. I have also developed a convenient and affordable grab and go lunch menu for the dashboard diner, the local trades and the workaholics who prefer to eat at their desks. A move was necessary!

The Next Step

I gave my notice for May 31st and took on a nearby location that has a fully functioning kitchen with space for 8 additional seats (42 now) , a prepared food freezer and product shelving, as well as a storefront next-door that is vacant should I feel the need to expand. I purchased tables from a local re-use store, The Real Deal and refinished them (actually my very supportive father did this for me). My parents gifted our family harvest kitchen table and benches (a communal table near electrical outlets for laptops), and a former landlord sold me chairs he was no longer using. I have managed to cover the unexpected costs of new plumbing after realizing the pipes had frozen and the recent electrical work that had been started and never finished. Additional cosmetic work has been done to pretty the place up and once electrical is sorted, I will schedule inspections to allow the doors to open for business.


My goal of expanding the Local Food Eatery I had started at 7 Russell Street West is nearing completion as I have embraced this move to 5 Main St. East opening under the name ‘NOAL in spite of the challenges I have faced. I will continue to produce farm to table focussed food on that same conventional convection oven from my first location, however I have launched this campaign is to raise the funds needed to outfit an efficient and professionally equipped kitchen.

Our Costs

The move has been made, the dining room is ready for service, and we are in need of the following items:

6 burner gas range

Refrigerated retail bunker 

Table top gas flat top griddle

Stand up retail freezer w glass doors

Table top char broiler 

Double ribbed panini press 

2 basket gas deep fryer w 4 baskets 

Commercial immersion blender

Gas convection oven with oven stand 

Kitchen Aid Commercial Mixer 

Refrigerated sandwich / work station

Labour / Installation / Permits

Impact

I have embraced this move with potential growth and by making a contribution to my campaign you will allow me to produce local foods for all, in a community that is at the beginning stages of embracing the local food movement. I will be able to produce more food, thus purchase more local product which will help to grow our local food economy and to help

Other Ways You Can Help

This campaign is not just about helping me grow my business, but it is also about supporting local farmers and producers. Make it a point to shop at your local Farmer’s Markets on a weekly basis, explore the local CSA (Community Supported Agriculture) options in your region.

Build Community

Lower Taxes

Strengthen Local Economy

Increase Options / Choices

Create a Healthier Environment

Create Jobs and Opportunities

Increase Wealth of Residents

Give Back to Your Community

Buy local, Eat Local, Shop Local!

story:
A little bit about us...

     Hot Box Tours owes it's conception to the two original co-founders Leo Ferguson and Tom Guida. Originally, they were college roommates studying at Florida International University until they decided to leave school and become entrepreneur business partners full time. They saw that the growing legal marijuana industry was cultivating a niche market of cannabis tourism that was being taken over by greed, so they decided that they would do something to change that. They wanted to provide a service accessible to the average person and thus Hot Box Tours was born, and is now striving to be the #1 cannabis tourism provider in Colorado.

What We Need & What You Get


Funding Financial Breakdown

Trailer     =     $5000

Trailer Fabrication     =     $7000

Smoking Accessories     =     $1000

Merchandise     =     $4000

Advertising     =     $2000

Team Living Expenses     =     $6000

Total     =     $25,000


Donor Rewards

(REWARDS ARE ACCUMULATIVE)

$5

A thank you email and graphic desktop wallpaper with your name.

$10

Free Hot Box poster + Shout out on all of our social media pages.

$20

Free Hot Box T-shirt

$50

Free tour pass. 

$100

Free tour pass for 6 months.

$250

Free tour pass for a year.

$500

Free tour pass for 3 years.


Free Pass Specifications

*Only valid for one person. (Multiple people can't use the same pass.)*


*Includes passenger ticket and goodie box.*


Timeline

Phase A: January 1st - March 10th

Stage 1: January 1st - February 10th: Planning

Stage 2: February 10th - March 10th: Funding

Phase B: March 10th - April 20th

Stage 1: March 10th - March 31st: Construction & Move

Stage 2: April 1st - April 20th: Pre-Opening & Opening


The Impact

     As of right now the only tickets available for a premium, in-depth marijuana tour around some of the best dispensaries in Colorado will run you anywhere from $400-$600. With your donation not only will you be bringing that price down to $40, not only will you be making two college roommates dreams come true, but you'll potentially have a personal hand in the growth of a new and upcoming industry. Marijuana tourism. We think it's kind of a big deal.


Risks & Challenges


Seed Funding

     The main hurdle we have to overcome is the seed funding needed to start the business. That's why we came here! We are determined and confident that we'll find the help we need from awesome, generous, and like-minded people just like you. Once we reach our goal of 25k it's off to the races, all the way to our grand opening on 4/20. 

What if we don't reach our goal?

     We believe Hot Box Tours can be a reality, and so do some of our investor friends. If we don't reach our goal, unfortunately we won't be able to open on 4/20 this year... But we'll be able to open this fall! That's right even if we don't reach our goal, the traction and initial funding we need to take the startup to investors will be covered. And Hot Box Tours will still be a go. 
Other Ways You Can Help

     Spread the word! Coming from college we understand that not everyone has the extra money to just give away, even if it's to a good cause. But one way you could help is by telling your friends about us, you can shout us out on Twitter, Instagram, and Facebook @hotboxtours. We'd really appreciate the help!

story:
Short Summary

  • Clackamas River Outfitters was founded in 2015 with a goal to expand the paddling opportunities on the Clackamas River. For years, private boaters have enjoyed the Clackamas River's scenic flat water and whitewater stretches. However, without the availability of a local source to rent gear, get instruction, or book a tour, access to more potential users has been limited.  
  • Clackamas River Outfitters has partnered with PGE (Portland General Electric) to expand our paddling rentals, tours, and instruction to Promontory Park. This spring, CRO will open our second location at the marina! Our expanded business will offer customers a second location, additional amenities, and more square miles to paddle. Now, is your opportunity to participate in the growth of Oregon's outdoor recreational activities by participating in building a vibrant paddling community on the scenic Clackamas River! 

  • Your generous contributions will help us grow our small business and expand sustainable recreation, conservation education, and allow more people too experience the Wild & Scenic Clackamas River in a low impact manner. 
  • By funding CRO's campaign, you will be directly assisting in expansion of sustainable recreation on the Wild & Scenic Clackamas River while simultaneously supporting vibrancy of the local economy. Choosing to contribute will result in the availability of fun, healthy and sustainable recreational opportunities. Our passion for paddling is matched by our connection to the natural world. We believe that by spending more time outdoors, we become more connected to our understanding of how the natural world supports our lives in so many wonderful ways and how what we do impacts the natural and wild places that sustain us.

What We Need & What You Get 

  • CRO is working hard to raise $15,000. These funds will go directly back into the expansion of our business. More specifically, your contribution will help us grow our kayak and paddleboard fleet and expand our marketing potential.   

  • In the event that we don't reach our entire goal…this campaign will still have been a success. The exposure our business will gain from this campaign is positive movement forward! Any funds will be used to obtain additional rentals so that we are able to provide quality access to paddling for CRO's second location. 

The Impact

  • This project is especially valuable to increasing use and awareness of our natural world. With the current status of climate and and water issues, we feel that our work is one of not only providing fun paddling activities but connecting people to what ultimately sustains us. We want contributors to know they will be assisting in the vibrancy of the local economy by supporting small sustainable business.
  • Last year was our first season in business. We were successful in fulfilling all our goals in the first year of operation. In a short period of time, we were able to secure funding, organize the structure and operational side of business and effectively execute our goals - a high quality, on-water kayak and paddleboard rental, tour and instruction business. We were able to re-invest in our company in the first season and change negative usage patterns for the better in an area that had previously been underutilized.
  • We LOVE what we do and want to share it with others in a meaningful way. The ability to increase our rental fleet will secure our operational viability and allow us to provide more access to paddling opportunities to more people. 

Risks & Challenges

  • Prior to opening CRO, no one was offering the services we were proposing. With a goal to provide flatwater paddling on Estacada Lake and North Fork Reservoir it was up to us to spread the word and build clientele. Where some see lack of services as a problem; we see opportunity. Our vision is to fill a niche in an area that has the resources but lacks services. With many years as a  certified kayak instructor, organizing paddling events, working with interest groups on recreation improvements, conservation work, and roots close to many of the areas local waterways, we have confidence that we are positioned to excel as the first company of its type in the area. 
  • The Estacada Lakeshore Path Cleanup is a great example of our commitment to the community around us. In 2015, CRO Organized the first ever 100% volunteer driven cleanup of the Estacada Lakeshore path! 


  • During the business planning phase, we thought long and hard about how we would overcome the hurdles before us. We knew the area was a hot-bed for paddling and many other outdoor activities. So, we reached out to the paddling community to help us spread the word. Along with our partners in the paddling and outdoor industry, we made a point to foster relations with county and state tourism boards, as well as local and metropolitan cities and organizations. Utilizing these sources along with the social media, we will continue to spread the word about our new business. 
  • We need everyone's support to be successful and whether it's making a financial contribution, sharing our campaign on social media, visiting one of our two locations to paddle, or telling a friend about our business we can't do it with out you! 
  •  Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word about our campaign!


Thank You 

~Luke & Tanley

Utilizing these sources along with the social media, we will continue to spread the word about our new business. 



We need everyone's support to be successful and whether it's making a financial contribution, sharing our campaign on social media, visiting one of our two locations to paddle, or telling a friend about our business we can't do it with out you!   Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word about our campaign! 



  Thank You ~Luke & Tanley

story:
HELP REPAIR THE WORLD BY SUPPORTING THE 2016-17 REPAIR THE WORLD FELLOWSHIP!

THE FELLOWSHIP
The Repair the World Fellowship is an 11-month opportunity for young adults ages 21 to 26 to engage and challenge the Jewish community to address social justice issues through meaningful volunteering. The Fellowship takes place in Detroit, New York City, Philadelphia, and Pittsburgh. The 2016-17 Fellowship will take place from August 15, 2016 through July 13, 2017. 


Our Fellowship is currently in its 3rd year and we are asking for your support in making the 4th year even bigger and better!


THE FELLOWS

Fellows recruit, train, and serve alongside volunteers to bring about real community change around education justice and food justice. The Repair the World fellows collaborate with peers to create thought-provoking events and volunteer experiences. They explore how Jewish values inform social justice work. Food Justice Fellows mobilize volunteers around community gardening, urban farming, projects at food pantries and soup kitchens, and converting vacant lots into community spaces. Education Justice Fellows mobilize volunteers around mentoring, early childhood literacy, running stimulating after-school programs, and developing education and employment programming for adults struggling with homelessness.

Supporting the RtW fellows supports local nonprofit organizations in our communities, by helping them strengthen their ability to do good work and make an impact on those they serve.

THE IMPACT

  • Repair the World fellows have more than tripled the number of individuals participating in our Communities programming from about 4,000 in our first year to over 12,000 in year 2.

  • In our first year, each fellow engaged on average 125 participants; in the second year, each fellow engaged an average 325 participants.

  • In the first year of our program, Repair fellows recruited 1,500 volunteers and in the second year, Repair fellows recruited 3,900 volunteers.  

  • In our second year, our fellows and volunteers served over 50,000 hours.

  • Repair fellows partnered with 39 nonprofits in five cities over our first two years.


YOUR SUPPORT

Our numbers show that our fellows are more than doubling their impact in these communities each year. Help us keep this amazing momentum going and support us in continuing to increase our impact in our 4th year! We need your help raising $25,000 to support the 2016-17 Repair the World Fellowship. 

Your contribution enables our fellows to continue to create more meaningful and impactful volunteer opportunities and community programming. Here are a few highlights from our cities that illustrate the variety of activities that your donation will support:

    • 39 teen participants in the Wexner Service Corps came to Repair the World Detroit for a week at the start of June to engage in education and food justice service opportunities. Participants also learned about the city of Detroit from native Detroiters. 

    • Repair the World New York City organized an alternative break program focused on food justice for participants from NYU, Columbia, Princeton and List College. Students participated in the Just Food Conference, followed by four days of service at RtW's partner organizations working on food justice and urban agriculture. 

    • Repair the World Pittsburgh volunteers worked with 412 Food Rescue to pack bags of food for students at Linden and Dilworth Elementary schools who qualify for free or reduced lunches. These children often are food insecure and may not have meals available to them at home on the weekends. 

    • Created by Repair the World Philadelphia, Philly Farm Crew seeks to increase access to sustainably grown food and offers volunteer opportunities at a variety of urban farms and gardens around Philadelphia, in addition to organized community-building events. Since August 2015, Philly Farm Crew has hosted 94 volunteers, including 74 first time volunteers. 

FROM OUR FELLOWS...

“While I was a Repair the World Fellow, I worked in a school that was severely underserved, but would also learn about what factors contributed to making the school that way, and why it was so different than the school five miles down the road. The combination of direct service, and learning about context (why things are the way they are) has really made me much more in tune with and informed about policy and ways to understand and approach broader, systemic issues.”
 - Jenna Summerfield, Repair the World Pittsburgh Fellow '14-'15

“As a fellow I had the opportunity to work with Keep Growing Detroit, an organization that exists to promote a food sovereign city, where the majority of fruits and vegetables Detroiters consume are grown by residents within the city’s limits.  One of their main events is a volunteer day in the fall. I was still pretty new to the Repair the World Fellowship at the time, and this volunteer day felt like a first “real” moment for me. I had helped plan it, done outreach, recruited volunteers, and supported key staff members. The day finally came and we were at the farm loading materials into a truck when it started POURING! It was too late to cancel, and we had already loaded all of the materials, so we drove over to the site. I thought for sure no one would show up in the rain - but there were at least 20 people there when we arrived! They were all ready to garden in the rain, despite the worst outdoor weather all year. We cleared a huge plot of space at the day-care center that day, started a new garden, and prepped veggies to start growing. We had a huge impact from start to finish, and saw the whole project carried out -  I felt so lucky to be part of this community of shared responsibility and dedication (even in the horrible weather!)” - Charlie Frank, Repair the World Detroit Fellow '14-'15


“Through this Fellowship I’ve learned a lot about what it means to be Jewish, and how people connect their Judaism to social justice and service. Even though I'm not Jewish, the whole idea of Tikkun Olam is very universal and relatable.” 
- Bridget Flynn, Repair the World Philadelphia Food Justice Team Leader '15-'16, Repair the World Philadelphia Fellow '14-'15

  Stay Connected with Repair the World and our fellows through our E-Newsletter! 

           Interested in the Repair the World Fellowship? Learn more & Apply.
story_txt:
HELP REPAIR THE WORLD BY SUPPORTING THE 2016-17 REPAIR THE WORLD FELLOWSHIP!
THE FELLOWSHIP
The Repair the World Fellowship is an 11-month opportunity for young adults ages 21 to 26 to engage and challenge the Jewish community to address social justice issues through meaningful volunteering. The Fellowship takes place in Detroit, New York City, Philadelphia, and Pittsburgh. The 2016-17 Fellowship will take place from August 15, 2016 through July 13, 2017. 
Our Fellowship is currently in its 3rd year and we are asking for your support in making the 4th year even bigger and better!THE FELLOWSFellows recruit, train, and serve alongside volunteers to bring about real community change around education justice and food justice. The Repair the World fellows collaborate with peers to create thought-provoking events and volunteer experiences. They explore how Jewish values inform social justice work. Food Justice Fellows mobilize volunteers around community gardening, urban farming, projects at food pantries and soup kitchens, and converting vacant lots into community spaces. Education Justice Fellows mobilize volunteers around mentoring, early childhood literacy, running stimulating after-school programs, and developing education and employment programming for adults struggling with homelessness.Supporting the RtW fellows supports local nonprofit organizations in our communities, by helping them strengthen their ability to do good work and make an impact on those they serve.THE IMPACTRepair the World fellows have more than tripled the number of individuals participating in our Communities programming from about 4,000 in our first year to over 12,000 in year 2.
In our first year, each fellow engaged on average 125 participants; in the second year, each fellow engaged an average 325 participants. 
In the first year of our program, Repair fellows recruited 1,500 volunteers and in the second year, Repair fellows recruited 3,900 volunteers.  
In our second year, our fellows and volunteers served over 50,000 hours.
Repair fellows partnered with 39 nonprofits in five cities over our first two years.




YOUR SUPPORT
Our numbers show that our fellows are more than doubling their impact in these communities each year. Help us keep this amazing momentum going and support us in continuing to increase our impact in our 4th year! We need your help raising $25,000 to support the 2016-17 Repair the World Fellowship. 


Your contribution enables our fellows to continue to create more meaningful and impactful volunteer opportunities and community programming. Here are a few highlights from our cities that illustrate the variety of activities that your donation will support:

39 teen participants in the Wexner Service Corps came to Repair the World Detroit for a week at the start of June to engage in education and food justice service opportunities. Participants also learned about the city of Detroit from native Detroiters. 
Repair the World New York City organized an alternative break program focused on food justice for participants from NYU, Columbia, Princeton and List College. Students participated in the Just Food Conference, followed by four days of service at RtW's partner organizations working on food justice and urban agriculture. 


Repair the World Pittsburgh volunteers worked with 412 Food Rescue to pack bags of food for students at Linden and Dilworth Elementary schools who qualify for free or reduced lunches. These children often are food insecure and may not have meals available to them at home on the weekends. 
Created by Repair the World Philadelphia, Philly Farm Crew seeks to increase access to sustainably grown food and offers volunteer opportunities at a variety of urban farms and gardens around Philadelphia, in addition to organized community-building events. Since August 2015, Philly Farm Crew has hosted 94 volunteers, including 74 first time volunteers.

“As a fellow I had the opportunity to work with Keep Growing Detroit, an organization that exists to promote a food sovereign city, where the majority of fruits and vegetables Detroiters consume are grown by residents within the city’s limits.  One of their main events is a volunteer day in the fall. I was still pretty new to the Repair the World Fellowship at the time, and this volunteer day felt like a first “real” moment for me. I had helped plan it, done outreach, recruited volunteers, and supported key staff members. The day finally came and we were at the farm loading materials into a truck when it started POURING! It was too late to cancel, and we had already loaded all of the materials, so we drove over to the site. I thought for sure no one would show up in the rain - but there were at least 20 people there when we arrived! They were all ready to garden in the rain, despite the worst outdoor weather all year. We cleared a huge plot of space at the day-care center that day, started a new garden, and prepped veggies to start growing. We had a huge impact from start to finish, and saw the whole project carried out -  I felt so lucky to be part of this community of shared responsibility and dedication (even in the horrible weather!)” - Charlie Frank, Repair the World Detroit Fellow '14-'15

Even though I'm not Jewish, the whole idea of Tikkun Olam is very universal and relatable.” - Bridget Flynn, Repair the World Philadelphia Food Justice Team Leader '15-'16, Repair the World Philadelphia Fellow '14-'15

story:
JOKKMOKK - kaas & dinges

[ENGLISH SUMMARY BELOW]
Eindhoven krijgt er een leuk plekje bij, als het aan ons ligt. In de loop van december opent op Bergstraat 35 in Eindhoven de kaas- en delicatessenwinkel Jokkmokk zijn deuren. Bij Jokkmokk kun je terecht voor mooie kazen en lekkere delicatessen waarbij vooral de passie van de makers en de smaak centraal zullen staan. Voor een ambachtelijke Hollandse boerenkaas, een lekkere schapenkaas uit de streek, een pittige blauwe kaas, een traditionele cheddar, de mooiste Franse kaasjes en nog veel meer kazen zul je hier terecht kunnen. En voor meer, uh, ja, dinges dus....

Jokkmokk heeft een zwak voor streekproducten, maar ook voor traditie, kleine gepassioneerde makers en natuurlijk voor hele lekkere smaken. Biologisch kan dan een plus zijn, ongepasteuriseerd is dat zeker. Maar voorop staan de zintuigen. Lekker, mooi, welriekend (of niet) en met een scala aan structuren zal het kaasaanbod weldoordacht maar niet buitensporig groot zijn. Iedere kaas heeft een verhaal, die verhalen willen we gaan vertellen, en dat kunnen we waarschijnlijk beter als het over 40 kazen gaat dan wanneer het over 200 stuks gaat.

Wat hebben we nodig

Een deel van de financiering is rond. Om die hele mooie kazen en lekkernijen naar Eindhoven te krijgen is echter nog extra geld nodig. Jij kunt daarbij helpen. Als je nu helpt het bedrag wat nog nodig is rond te krijgen krijg je je inleg terug in kaas (of wijn, of olie, of uh, dinges). Als je niet vaak in Eindhoven komt, kunnen we het ook in de vorm van een lening doen die je over drie jaar met rente (6% per jaar) terugkrijgt.

Waar gaat het geld in zitten?

Mede door jouw bijdrage kan het volgende tot stand gaan komen:

  • een mooi assortiment, bestaande uit streekproducten, ongepasteuriseerde Holandse kazen, kazen en producten van verder weg die met heel veel passie zijn gemaakt en alle verhalen die daarbij horen.
  • een mooi ingericht winkelpand waarin die producten mooi tot zijn recht kunnen komen.
  • de armslag om ook in promotie en communicatie te investeren zodat er ruchtbaarheid komt over deze mooie plek in de even mooie Bergstraat.

Risico's

Als het geld niet voor 100% ingezameld kan worden, dan betekent het dat een paar onderdelen van de winkel in fases gerealiseerd zullen gaan worden. Het betekent dus niet dat JOKKMOKK er niet komt. €4500,- is als streefbedrag bepaald, meer is  zeker welkom en kan goed gebruikt worden voor nog meer mooie dingen.

Andere manieren om te helpen

Als je JOKKMOKK nou niet financieel verder kunt helpen, maar ons wel een warm hart toedraagt. Deel deze pagina dan met je vrienden en nodig hun uit contact te zoeken en te steunen. 

De Bergstraat gaat er een mooie plek voor Eindhovense foodies bij krijgen!

English summary

In December a new cheese and delicatessen shop is going to open up in Eindhoven's Bergstraat. A shop specialized in regional cheeses, unpasteurized cheeses and cheeses and other products from passionate makers from the Netherlands and beyond. 

We want to make a difference and you can help us by contributing to this crowd funding campaign. And the good thing is, you'll get your loan paid back in cheese. Get in contact with us if you need any more information. Liking us on the social media is very much appreciated as well.
